NewsDetail.Name: Mentored Student Research at BYU-Idaho
NewsDetail.Title: Mentored Student Research at BYU-Idaho
NewsDetail.Author: Glenn Embree
NewsDetail.BodyCopy:
Mentored student research is a student-faculty collaboration to examine, develop, and communicate new knowledge or works in ways appropriate to a wide variety of disciplines. This activity is called by many names, including: undergraduate research, experiential learning, scholarly and creative activity, disciplinary practice, and investigative studies.

 

During the Fall semester of 2009, Fenton Broadhead commissioned a committee to study the potential benefits of providing more student research and creative work opportunities at BYU-Idaho and to make recommendations as to how to organize the development of these activities. It soon became evident that small-scale mentored research projects that focus on developing real life experiential learning for students have significant benefits. Mentored student research experiences:

 

  1. Provide students with opportunities to synthesize what they learn in the classroom and to practice at a professional level.
  2. Develop connections that open pathways to internships, graduate schools, and employment.
  3. Enhance faculty professional development efforts by enabling them to mentor students, collaborate with other professionals within and outside the University, take research into the classroom, and keep up with developments in their respective fields.This, in turn, helps them become better teachers.
  4. Build closer and stronger relationships with other educational and professional institutions.

 

The guiding principle behind mentored research activities on the BYU-Idaho campus is that they will focus on student and faculty learning.

 

The Mentored Student Research Committee has recently been asked to continue to function under the title of Explorations Committee. This committee is one of seven committees that operate under the auspices of the Learning and Teaching Council. Their efforts are at the hub of campus student research activities and (1) encourage and support undergraduate research, (2) maintain and provide access to programs that train students and faculty on research opportunities and resources, (3) oversee opportunities for written and oral presentation of student research and creative works, and (4) facilitate communication between campus groups and other organizations.

 

In order to streamline and consolidate support efforts for mentored student research, the existing structure for approving faculty fellowships has been modified so that student/faculty research teams apply to one place for faculty release time and (if needed) financial resources.

 

The Southeast Idaho Research Institute (SIRI) is currently being formed to help support our efforts. It will be a non-profit corporation designed to promote and help fund scientific research in our area, and to expand collaborative efforts between BYU-Idaho students and faculty and researchers from other regional universities, research centers, and industry. SIRI will be similar in function and organization to the Eastern Idaho Entrepreneurial Center, which has provided excellent internship opportunities for numerous BYU-Idaho students.
